title: Rebuilding a broken industry from scratch (Modern Animal's Steven Eidelman) | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: the thing that you're looking for as an
entrepreneur is the the sort of uh
inevitability of demand for the product
or service you're offering. And if
you're pushing a rock uphill, you don't
have it. Mhm. Steven is the CEO and
co-founder of Modern Animal. It's a
fascinating disruptor in the pet care
industry. Steven saw a noble profession
in dire need of change and he wanted to
help. the veterinarian was really
struggling and the consumer or the pet
owner, the customer was being left
behind as well. And so, interestingly,
we're we're talking about animals, but
it's the people who are suffering. And
obviously, if they're suffering, the
animals probably not getting the care
that they need, too. So, it was the core
veterary care delivery system that was
broken. I was starting to get really
close to the problems in this industry,
and I started to really deeply care
about them. And once you see problems as
an entrepreneur, it's really hard to
turn away from them. Modern Animal now
has about 600 employees and a rapidly
expanding footprint of pet care clinics.
This week, Steven Idleman reveals the
lessons learned by scaling his
revolutionary approach to veterinary
care.
This is Masters of
Scale. I'm Jeff Berman, your host.
Steven Idleman's scale journey with
modern animal is an inspiring
entrepreneurial story. But Steven didn't
grow up with the rosiest picture of
being your own boss. Steven, welcome to
Masters of Scale. Thanks, Chef. Great to
be here. As a first generation American
with parents from the former Soviet
Union, Steven watched his dad work
incredibly long hours running a
business. He saw every drop of his dad's
sweat and the late nights toiling at the
kitchen table along the way. So Steven
opted to start his career in a more
traditional office environment as a
consultant at Bane. But a few years in,
he started to wonder if he'd been wrong
about the life of an entrepreneur. I
think that the the hardest part
about watching sort of you know the the
immigrant entrepreneur journey and
trying to make sense of it as a you know
first generation uh aspiring
entrepreneur is what my what my father
did was he fought for survival. It
wasn't a career choice. So for them it
was hey this is about security and
stability and having the best
opportunities and taking advantage of
them. But for me that the
entrepreneurial thing that I was
experiencing you know with my father was
really building something like what does
it feel like to build something and I
was seeing that as an investor um and
what I learned was you know I'm never
going to take that leap um if I just use
my rational part of my brain right
there's always going to be some reason
why it's not a good enough idea why why
there's a risk. Um and so I didn't know
what to make of that. So this was around
2012. Uh I'm
about let's see 5 years into my career.
Uh so I'm about 26 27 years old and the
itch is is is starting to get more like
a severe you know burning sensation and
you might need to see a doctor for that.
Yeah. Exactly. Yeah.
Probably. And uh you know I think that
at the time there I'm I'm looking at
businesses you know every day dozens of
businesses right? So I don't really know
anything about anything. I don't have a
business that I'm deeply passionate
about. I've been a generalist my whole
career as a student and as a
professional now. And so that is a
difficult place to know that there's a
problem you deeply want to solve, right?
And so just desperately wanting to be an
entrepreneur, well that's not what my
father did, right? Um that's not what
most great entrepreneurs have done. So
it's a tough place to actually pursue
that dream from. But at some point I had
to take the leap. And so it happened
pretty uh organically just my roommate
at the time who who at this point become
you know one of my closest friends he
was a colleague of mine from Bane. He
also worked at an investing firm. We had
a whiteboard and this is like an episode
out of Silicon Valley
right on the whiteboard. Um it just so
happens that when we were at Bane
together there were a number of petare
companies that were clients and my first
case that I ever worked on was actually
a petare case. And so what I learned at
that time was this is a much bigger
industry than people realize. There's a
lot of emotional connection to it. And
what we were thinking about at the time
was this industry is about to change
dramatically with a younger pet owner
coming in. Millennials are different and
we saw this across a bunch of different
categories. We said, "Okay, this is a
really large industry and people are
ignoring it." So I think the way that
Ben, my co-founder, and I came to to
even end up in this industry was we
couldn't agree on anything else. and we
both have been dog lovers our whole
lives and we grew up with dogs and there
was just a much deeper connection to
that relationship that we were both able
to access as very sort of emotive people
um than anything else on that
whiteboard. And so the investor actually
that Ben worked for um is a great
entrepreneur himself and and he he
really encouraged us to to pursue
something that we you know we're both
excited about and to work together. He
said, "You need to work with someone
that you really trust and you will go to
war with." So, you had the the
co-founders, you're not alone on this
journey. You had a category, you saw
opportunity. Um, what was it about what
was changing with millennials growing
into pet ownership where you saw the
opportunity and what what became that
that first entrepreneurial
entrepreneurial dive for you? The thing
that we were most interested in was the
shift around specifically pet health.
the tailwinds that were supporting sort
of that shift where you think about
generations ago, the dog used to live
outside, right? More recently, the dog
started to live
inside. Even more recently, the dog is
no longer, you know, just inside and,
you know, in their dog bed. They're in
your bed, right? So, that has a lot of
implications. You know, what are you
expecting of a service provider or a
product that you're purchasing for your
pet? How much are you willing to spend
on your pet? Um, and in parallel, what's
been happening is medicine's just gotten
better, right? I mean, the way animal
health works is that it benefits from
all innovation and improvement to human
health. And so, greater medicine is
becoming available and people want
access to that. And the willingness to
spend on on on pets has increased. So,
the the expectations of what's available
in the market have changed. Now, in
2012, what we saw was mostly that it
seemed as though the whole world was
going to revolve around devices that
captured information in our world,
right? I'm wearing an order ring now,
but back then it was Fitbit. I was
always interested in that category
because I'm type 1 diabetic. And I'm
somewhat of a robot. I have an insulin
pump. I have a, you know, continuous
glucose monitor on my arm. Um, and so
for me, the idea of capturing this data
to improve health was something I've
been fascinated by for a long time. And
you know essentially we took those ideas
of you know devices for health, pet
care, the trends around pet health and
smashed them together. And that was our
first company. It was called Whistle.
And and I I I am inferring that there
was also an understanding that for
people with disposable income, there is
a you like not a lot of price
sensitivity when it comes to doing right
by your pet. That's right. Okay. So, so
what exactly was Whistle and and how how
did you get it off the ground? So
whistle was the idea that we want to
connect the pet uh the pet owner with
the veterinarian. And so what's the best
way to do that? Because the veterinarian
used to always be the most trusted
resource if you were if you're a pet
owner. And this was around the time
where we're starting to now Google
everything, right? And in parallel, the
veterinarian sort of losing that sway
and that uh role of influence. And so we
thought, hey, let's capture this
valuable data. And you know, we're
dreaming big. We're think we're going to
put a device on an animal. we're going
to be able to tell everything that's
going on with them, right? Uh whether or
not the technology existed at the time
is a separate separate uh point, but uh
that was the vision. We put put a device
on, capture all this information, and
translate it for the veterinarian so
that there's this connection between the
veterinarian and and the client, the pet
owner uh when they're at home. So, it's
a pet wearable where the vet can log on
and see the vitals, see any key key data
point that they need to see to help
diagnose what's happening with the pet.
And so the most interesting thing of
that building that company beyond sort
of all the entrepreneurial journeys of
raising capital, hiring, firing, you
know, pushing yourself as as an
entrepreneur to grow, um, the most
interesting part about it was that
dynamic that you just described, that's
what invited us into the veterary
practice for the first time. And what we

data isn't helping their dayto-day,
which is already almost an impossible
task to get through. If you just take a

base level, what is a veterinarian
doing? First of all, a veterinarian goes
to medical school for four years, comes
out with a load of debt, right? They
have to study multiple species. They're
doing everything at a general practice
veterary practice, right? There's
emergency hospitals and there's
specialists, but let's just talk about a
general practice, which is what modern
animal does. You're doing at a small
animal hospital, you're doing dog and
cat, maybe you're even doing exotics,
but let's say we're just doing dog and
cat. You're doing everything from
wellness care, preventative care,
vaccines, lab work to urgent care. Um
you're doing surgery, soft tissue
surgery, you're doing dentistry, you're
doing radiology. Um you're doing
euthanasia.
Um so you're going from one moment where
you're you got a family who's excited
about their first appointment with their
new puppy and then the next you've got,
you know, authia appointment and you're
doing that 15 20 25 times a day. um
you've got clients who they're not the
actual patient, right? So, you have this
sort of interesting dynamic that is more
akin to sort of if you have a child and
you go to a pediatrician where you're
talking about this third
party who is the recipient of the care,
but you're kind of negotiating between
these two other people, the practitioner
and the, you know, in our case, the
client who cares so deeply about this
being that can't communicate. And it can
get antagonistic pretty quickly. And
what you have is a population of people
veterinarians who the only motivation to
become a veterinarian is to care for
animals. Like all of the rest of us may
have all these ulterior motives. I have
some deep-seated sort of thing from my
childhood about becoming an entrepreneur
and proving myself to my parents.
Probably veterinarians just love
animals. They're like the most pure
noble people I've ever met. So you have
this person right who is there purely to
solve for the issues that that animal
has but now they have to negotiate cost
veterary care is you know is expensive
because you're paying full freight like
we all forget for our own healthcare
somebody's usually paying part of the
way
whether it's you know Medicare and the
government's paying for it your employer
you're paying your co-ay or your you
know your premiums. Um, so with veterary
care, as medicine becomes more
available, it's just getting more

relationship between the pet owner and
the veterinarian where they have to

we can't even afford to do the

Let's just treat, keep it, you know,
let's take our best guess of what's

Chewy is charging $5 less for the same

there's a lack of transparency. So, the
pet owner is experiencing a pretty
sub-optimal experience often times, but
the veterinarian is really struggling,
especially today. A lot has changed.
Super helpful framework. So, I just want
to take a half step back and then then
roll us forward. um when you come up

hey I will fund this idea let's go for
it really difficult to say no to that

connected hardware at that right I mean
that's That's an extraordinary advantage

Yeah. And so that was it. We went off to

with incredible industrial
designers. As a young entrepreneur, it

before. And about a year in, we launched

know, I'm looking at the data, right?
And it's obvious to me I don't think
people want this thing. So the wearable
that we built at first was health
tracking in theory, but really was

same way Fitbit was meant to be a a

counter, right?
And we learned pretty quickly that what

something we could do yet, which was
what a broader array of features and
specifically location tracking was
something that people assumed if I'm
putting a device on my dog, I want to

important to us. That was what got us

industry. And so we got a lot of

much more quickly being a part of a

conversation, realized they're actually
huge in pet as well. Um uh a lot of

um
to create something more interesting as

So what we learned was you know the

Um and for me it got really clear that
to solve the problems this industry had
not just the exciting opportunity of how
if you connect all these things um how

there's a lot of problems and I didn't I

as a young entrepreneur who doesn't

once you see problems as an

what was happening in the same time

Everything in the in the veterary space

and it basically was that people figured

a family who cared very deeply and had a
a really exciting vision but a huge

There's a lot of downsides to technology
as well, but I believe the technology

positive ways. And so I wanted to bring

tough to do at that large of a scale.
Sure. And so I ultimately decided to go
do it outside. But the private equity
rollups and that model that were, you
know, happening in parallel elsewhere,
um, where you would have, you know, sort
of shadow private equity firms buying up
mom and pop clinics. The motto of one of

we're not going to do anything once we

So, you know, Dr. Jeff's that clinic,
um, we're going to leave your clinic as

where I I imagine you looked at a lot of

and how might we create an alternative

it's to bring humanity back to veterary

relationship. The animal is the

For us it was you know really

how do you make that experience better

with with him typically. Um now the cost

you you launch your own clinics, right?
I mean, just just take us through like
what what what the whole thing is end to
end. So, we build our own clinics from
scratch. They're about 3,000 square feet
on average. Have about six to seven
doctors when they're full. Um, and about

we have a membership based model. Every

we're actually about to roll out a tier
that lets people who don't want to come
as much um still be able to come and

you can access Modern Animal anywhere.
So you can go to any of our locations.
Everybody has our mobile app on their
phone. We have 247 virtual care
available which is uh access to our team
through phone chat video. You have full

medical records in the app. You can book

if if if my dog needs a a checkup, is

that the checkup determines they need

like how does it how does it actually

And this was, I think, reflective of

but it was also, hey, I can go on

Um, hey, veterary care is expensive. I'm
just not going to go. So, what I saw was

see is our members come twice as much on

cycle at Modern Animal earlier than

because we've removed that friction. So
whether that's happening virtually
through a triage video chat at 11:00 at
